title: Critical Illness Myopathy/Neuropathy
scope: ** Diagnosis, management, and rehabilitation of ICU-acquired weakness (ICUAW) including critical illness myopathy (CIM), critical illness polyneuropathy (CIP), and combined CIM/CIP (CINM). Covers risk factor identification and modification, electrodiagnostic differentiation (NCS/EMG including direct muscle stimulation), MRC sum score assessment, supportive management, early mobilization, ventilator liberation strategies, nutritional optimization, and long-term prognosis. Excludes pre-existing neuromuscular disorders (GBS, myasthenia gravis, ALS), spinal cord injury, and prolonged neuromuscular blockade effect without underlying neuromyopathy.

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Baseline; infection screen; leukocytosis suggests ongoing sepsis as risk factor for ICUAW
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; leukocytosis or bandemia suggest active infection

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Electrolytes (K, Mg, Ca, Phos affect muscle function); renal/hepatic function; glucose control assessment
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal; hyperglycemia >180 mg/dL requires insulin adjustment; electrolyte correction

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypomagnesemia worsens weakness and impairs neuromuscular transmission
Hypophosphatemia causes profound muscle weakness including respiratory muscles; may mimic or worsen ICUAW
Hypocalcemia increases neuromuscular excitability; hypercalcemia causes weakness
Elevated in CIM (often moderately 1000-5000 IU/L); very high levels suggest rhabdomyolysis; normal in CIP
Essential/Core Labs.target: Mildly to moderately elevated in CIM; normal in CIP; >10,000 suggests rhabdomyolysis

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hyperglycemia is a major modifiable risk factor for ICUAW; target 140-180 mg/dL per NICE-SUGAR
Assess ventilation (PaCO2) and oxygenation; hypercapnia indicates respiratory muscle weakness contributing to ventilator dependence
Essential/Core Labs.target: Normal: pH 7.35-7.45, PaCO2 35-45; rising PaCO2 suggests respiratory muscle failure

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Elevated in sepsis and tissue hypoperfusion; ongoing sepsis perpetuates ICUAW
Distinguish ongoing infection from inflammatory state; persistent sepsis worsens ICUAW prognosis
Essential/Core Labs.target: <0.5 ng/mL; elevated suggests active infection requiring treatment

Essential/Core Labs.rationale: Hypothyroid myopathy can mimic CIM; critical illness may cause sick euthyroid syndrome
UTI as source of ongoing sepsis; myoglobinuria if rhabdomyolysis
Essential/Core Labs.target: Negative; dark urine may indicate myoglobinuria

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Muscle injury marker; may be elevated in CIM alongside CK; supports myopathic process
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Elevated in CIM; normal in CIP

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Non-specific marker of tissue damage; elevated in myopathy and hemolysis
Muscle breakdown marker; elevated in CIM and rhabdomyolysis; renal toxicity risk
Myoglobinuria from muscle breakdown; renal injury risk
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive indicates significant muscle damage

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Exclude GBS if clinical presentation unclear; GBS can develop during ICU stay
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: Negative; positive suggests GBS rather than ICUAW

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Exclude myasthenia gravis if weakness pattern suggests NMJ disorder
Exclude MuSK-positive myasthenia if AChR negative but MG suspected
Adrenal insufficiency from prolonged steroid use causing weakness; critical illness-related corticosteroid insufficiency
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: AM cortisol >10 mcg/dL generally adequate; <10 suggests insufficiency

Extended Workup (Second-line).rationale: Hypothyroid myopathy in differential; thyroid dysfunction assessment
Deficiency is common in ICU patients and contributes to muscle weakness and impaired recovery
Nutritional status marker; low levels indicate protein malnutrition affecting muscle recovery
Chronic glycemic control assessment; poorly controlled diabetes increases ICUAW risk
Extended Workup (Second-line).target: <7% in general; assess baseline diabetes control

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Paraneoplastic neuromyopathy in differential if cancer history or atypical features
Lambert-Eaton myasthenic syndrome (LEMS) in differential; associated with small cell lung cancer
Inflammatory myopathy in differential if CK markedly elevated and atypical course
Toxic neuropathy mimic; occupational or environmental exposure
Acute intermittent porphyria mimic (motor neuropathy, autonomic dysfunction)
Definitive differentiation CIM vs CIP when electrodiagnostics are inconclusive; shows thick filament (myosin) loss in CIM; rarely needed in practice
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: CIM: selective loss of thick (myosin) filaments, type 2 fiber atrophy, necrosis; CIP: denervation changes, grouped atrophy

Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.rationale: Rarely indicated; axonal degeneration in CIP; only when diagnosis is uncertain and alternative treatable diagnoses are considered
Rare/Specialized (Refractory or Atypical.target: CIP: axonal degeneration of sensory and motor fibers; no inflammation

Essential/First-line.timing: When ICUAW suspected (typically after 1 week ICU stay with new weakness); ideally after sedation lightened to allow cooperation
Essential/First-line.target: CIP: reduced CMAP and SNAP amplitudes with normal conduction velocities (axonal pattern); CIM: reduced CMAP amplitudes with NORMAL SNAPs and myopathic MUP recruitment; Combined CINM: both axonal neuropathic and myopathic changes
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Anticoagulation (relative for needle EMG); unable to cooperate for volitional EMG

Essential/First-line.timing: When CIM vs CIP differentiation needed in uncooperative or sedated patients; specialized technique
Essential/First-line.target: CIM: reduced ratio of nerve-stimulated CMAP to direct muscle-stimulated CMAP (nerve:muscle ratio <0.5); CIP: preserved ratio with reduced CMAPs on both
Essential/First-line.contraindications: Requires specialized equipment; not widely available

Essential/First-line.timing: On recognition of ICUAW; baseline for ventilator weaning assessment
Essential/First-line.target: Atelectasis, pleural effusion, diaphragm elevation (weakness), aspiration

Essential/First-line.timing: Baseline; electrolyte abnormalities may cause arrhythmia; autonomic dysfunction assessment
Essential/First-line.target: Sinus rhythm; check for QTc prolongation, electrolyte-related changes

Essential/First-line.timing: Assess diaphragm thickness and excursion; predicts ventilator weaning success; diaphragm atrophy develops within 48-72h of mechanical ventilation
Essential/First-line.target: Diaphragm thickness >2mm; thickening fraction >30% during inspiration; excursion >10mm; decreased values suggest diaphragm atrophy and prolonged weaning

Essential/First-line.timing: Quantify muscle wasting; serial measurements track progression; cross-sectional area decreases significantly within first week of ICU
Essential/First-line.target: Reduced muscle thickness and cross-sectional area compared to admission baseline; echogenicity changes suggest myopathic process

Extended.item: MRI spine (whole) with and without contrast (CPT 72156)
Extended.timing: If spinal cord pathology suspected (upper motor neuron signs, sensory level)
Extended.target: Normal spinal cord; exclude compressive myelopathy, epidural abscess, infarction
Extended.contraindications: Pacemaker, metallic implants; patient stability for transport

Extended.item: MRI brain with and without contrast (CPT 70553)
Extended.timing: If central cause of weakness suspected (stroke, brainstem lesion)
Extended.target: Normal; exclude stroke, demyelination, structural lesion

Extended.timing: At 2-4 weeks if initial study inconclusive or to assess prognosis and track recovery
Extended.target: Evolution of findings; persistent denervation predicts slower recovery; reinnervation signs suggest improvement

Extended.timing: When patient can cooperate; assess respiratory muscle strength for weaning readiness; outpatient monitoring of recovery
Extended.target: FVC, MIP, MEP values; FVC >15 mL/kg supports weaning; serial improvement documents recovery

Extended.timing: If pulmonary pathology suspected (PE, empyema) complicating weaning failure
Extended.target: Pulmonary embolism; pleural effusion; lung pathology

Rare/Specialized.timing: When inflammatory myopathy in differential; assesses muscle edema and fatty infiltration
Rare/Specialized.target: CIM: diffuse muscle edema on STIR; inflammatory myopathy: focal/multifocal edema and enhancement

Rare/Specialized.timing: Diaphragm paralysis evaluation when ultrasound is equivocal; paradoxical diaphragm motion
Rare/Specialized.target: Normal bilateral diaphragm excursion; paradoxical motion indicates paralysis
Rare/Specialized.contraindications: Radiation exposure; patient must be transported

Rare/Specialized.timing: Assess phrenic nerve function directly; CIP may involve phrenic nerves causing diaphragm weakness
Rare/Specialized.target: Reduced phrenic CMAP amplitude suggests CIP involving phrenic nerve; normal suggests preserved phrenic function

dosing.instructions: Insulin infusion per ICU protocol; target glucose 140-180 mg/dL (NICE-SUGAR target); avoid hypoglycemia <70 mg/dL; transition to subcutaneous when tolerating enteral nutrition

Acute/Emergent.contraindications: Hypoglycemia risk; requires frequent glucose monitoring
Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Glucose q1-2h during infusion; q4-6h when stable; watch for hypokalemia

dosing.instructions: 40 mg SC daily; adjust for renal function (CrCl <30: 30 mg SC daily or use UFH)

Acute/Emergent.monitoring: Platelets q3 days; anti-Xa if renal impairment; signs of bleeding

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain from CIP (burning, tingling, allodynia); common in recovery phase

dosing.instructions: Start 300 mg PO qHS; titrate by 300 mg/day q1-3 days; target 900-1800 mg/day divided TID; max 3600 mg/day; dose adjust for renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation, dizziness, peripheral edema; renal function for dose adjustment

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain alternative to gabapentin; may be better tolerated

dosing.instructions: Start 75 mg PO BID; increase to 150 mg BID after 3-7 days; max 300 mg BID (600 mg/day); dose adjust for renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: Sedation, weight gain, peripheral edema; renal function

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Neuropathic pain and concurrent depression; dual benefit in ICUAW recovery

dosing.instructions: Start 30 mg PO daily x 1 week, then increase to 60 mg daily; max 120 mg/day

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe hepatic impairment; concurrent MAOIs; uncontrolled narrow-angle glaucoma
Symptomatic Treatments.monitoring: LFTs; blood pressure; serotonin syndrome signs; mood

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Musculoskeletal pain and general discomfort from immobility

dosing.instructions: 650-1000 mg PO/IV q6h; max 4 g/day (2 g/day if hepatic impairment)

Symptomatic Treatments.contraindications: Severe liver disease; hepatic impairment (reduce max dose)

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: ICU delirium prevention and sleep-wake cycle restoration; disrupted sleep worsens ICUAW

dosing.instructions: 3-5 mg PO qHS; administer at consistent time to promote circadian rhythm

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Constipation from immobility and opioid use

dosing.instructions: 100 mg PO BID

Symptomatic Treatments.indication: Constipation when docusate alone is insufficient

dosing.instructions: 8.6-17.2 mg PO qHS; may increase to BID

dosing.instructions: 17 g PO daily dissolved in 8 oz water

dosing.instructions: Start 25-50 mg PO daily; titrate by 25-50 mg q1-2 weeks; max 200 mg/day

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Neuropathic pain refractory to gabapentin/pregabalin; also helps insomnia

dosing.instructions: Start 10-25 mg PO qHS; titrate by 10-25 mg q1-2 weeks; max 150 mg/day

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: ECG at baseline and if dose >100 mg; anticholinergic side effects; QTc

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Localized neuropathic pain; adjunctive to systemic agents

dosing.instructions: Apply up to 3 patches to painful area for 12h on/12h off

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Allergy to amide anesthetics; broken skin at application site

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Severe fatigue and cognitive impairment during ICUAW recovery when non-pharmacologic measures insufficient

dosing.instructions: Start 5 mg PO BID (morning and noon); max 20 mg BID; avoid afternoon dosing to prevent insomnia

Second-line/Refractory.contraindications: Severe anxiety; cardiac arrhythmia; uncontrolled hypertension; concurrent MAOIs
Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Blood pressure; heart rate; appetite; sleep; mood; abuse potential

Second-line/Refractory.indication: Persistent fatigue during ICUAW recovery; alternative to methylphenidate

dosing.instructions: Start 100 mg PO daily in AM; max 200 mg daily

Second-line/Refractory.monitoring: Blood pressure; hepatic function; mood; sleep

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Prevention and treatment of ICUAW; reduces duration of mechanical ventilation and ICU length of stay

dosing.instructions: Phase 1 (passive ROM) within 24-48h of ICU admission; Phase 2 (active-assisted exercises) when patient alert; Phase 3 (sitting, standing, ambulation) when hemodynamically stable; minimum 20-30 min sessions BID

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.pretreatment: Hemodynamic stability (MAP >65, no active vasopressor uptitration); adequate oxygenation (FiO2 <0.6, PEEP <10); no active arrhythmia; no active hemorrhage
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Active hemorrhage; unstable fractures; severe hemodynamic instability requiring high-dose vasopressors; acute MI; unsecured airway
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Heart rate, blood pressure, SpO2 during sessions; RASS sedation score; MRC sum score weekly

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Minimize corticosteroid exposure as major risk factor for CIM; taper to lowest effective dose as rapidly as clinically feasible

dosing.instructions: Reassess corticosteroid indication daily; taper to lowest effective dose; discontinue if not clearly indicated; avoid concurrent use with NMBAs when possible

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.pretreatment: Document clear indication for continued steroids; review alternatives
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Do not abruptly discontinue if patient has been on >7 days (adrenal suppression risk)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Glucose (steroid-induced hyperglycemia); blood pressure; adrenal function if tapering after prolonged course

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Minimize NMBA exposure as risk factor for ICUAW; use train-of-four monitoring to avoid deep paralysis

doseOptions.orderSentence: Neuromuscular blocking agent (NMBA) minimization Individualized IV

dosing.instructions: If NMBA required (e.g., ARDS, refractory ICP), use lowest effective dose guided by train-of-four (TOF) monitoring; target 1-2/4 twitches; daily sedation/paralysis vacation if feasible; discontinue NMBA as soon as clinically possible
dosing.orderSentence: Neuromuscular blocking agent (NMBA) minimization Individualized IV

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.pretreatment: Document clear indication (severe ARDS, refractory ICP, open abdomen)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Concurrent high-dose corticosteroids (greatly increases CIM risk); avoid unless absolutely necessary
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Train-of-four q4h; daily attempt to discontinue; document indication daily

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Protein supplementation to support muscle preservation and recovery; protein catabolism is accelerated in ICUAW

dosing.instructions: Target protein 1.2-2.0 g/kg/day (adjusted body weight if obese); initiate enteral nutrition within 24-48h of ICU admission; caloric target 25-30 kcal/kg/day; avoid overfeeding

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.pretreatment: Functional GI tract; hemodynamic stability (MAP >60 on stable or decreasing vasopressors)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: GI obstruction; uncontrolled shock (delay until resuscitated); bowel ischemia
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Prealbumin weekly; nitrogen balance; feeding tolerance (residuals); glucose

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Target glucose 140-180 mg/dL to reduce ICUAW incidence; hyperglycemia independently increases CIM/CIP risk

doseOptions.orderSentence: Tight glycemic control protocol Insulin per protocol IV/SC

dosing.instructions: IV insulin infusion in ICU targeting 140-180 mg/dL; transition to basal-bolus SC insulin when tolerating nutrition; avoid tight control <110 (increased mortality per NICE-SUGAR)
dosing.orderSentence: Tight glycemic control protocol Insulin per protocol IV/SC

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Adrenal insufficiency (may require stress-dose steroids before aggressive glucose control)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: Glucose q1-2h on infusion; q4-6h on SC insulin; HbA1c at discharge

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.indication: Daily sedation interruption and light sedation targets reduce ICUAW risk and facilitate early mobilization

doseOptions.orderSentence: Sedation minimization protocol RASS target -1 to 0 IV

dosing.instructions: Daily spontaneous awakening trial (SAT); target RASS -1 to 0; use analgesia-first approach (pain, delirium, then sedation); prefer dexmedetomidine or propofol over benzodiazepines (benzodiazepines increase delirium and ICUAW risk)
dosing.orderSentence: Sedation minimization protocol RASS target -1 to 0 IV

Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.pretreatment: Pain adequately controlled; no active seizures; no procedures requiring deep sedation
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.contraindications: Active seizures; procedures requiring deep sedation; severe agitation endangering patient safety (titrate to lowest necessary level)
Disease-Modifying or Chronic Therapies.monitoring: RASS q4h; CAM-ICU for delirium BID; pain assessment

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consultation for diagnosis confirmation and electrodiagnostic planning (NCS/EMG) to differentiate CIM, CIP, and alternative diagnoses
Physical therapy for early mobilization protocol initiation, passive/active ROM exercises, progressive strengthening, and functional mobility training
Occupational therapy for upper extremity strengthening, ADL retraining, adaptive equipment assessment, and fine motor recovery
Speech-language pathology for swallowing evaluation given risk of pharyngeal weakness and aspiration in ICUAW patients
Respiratory therapy for ventilator weaning protocols, tracheostomy care, pulmonary rehabilitation, and secretion management
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) for comprehensive rehabilitation planning and disposition (inpatient rehab vs skilled nursing facility)
Nutrition/Dietitian for enteral nutrition optimization, protein target (1.2-2.0 g/kg/day), caloric assessment, and micronutrient supplementation
Pulmonology for ventilator management optimization, weaning strategies, and tracheostomy decision if prolonged ventilation anticipated
Pain management for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first-line gabapentinoids
Social work for discharge planning, family support, insurance authorization for rehabilitation, and community resources
Psychology/Psychiatry for ICU-acquired PTSD, depression, anxiety, and cognitive dysfunction screening and treatment
Palliative care for goals-of-care discussion if severe ICUAW with poor prognosis, prolonged ventilator dependence, or significant comorbidities

Patient Instructions.item: Recovery from ICU-acquired weakness typically takes weeks to months; CIM generally recovers faster than CIP (inform patient and family to set expectations)
Participate actively in all physical and occupational therapy sessions as tolerated to maximize recovery potential
Report new or worsening weakness, numbness, tingling, or breathing difficulty to medical team immediately (may indicate complication or alternative diagnosis)
Continue home exercise program as prescribed by physical therapy between formal sessions to maintain gains
Fall precautions: use assistive devices (walker, cane) as recommended; remove tripping hazards at home; do not attempt stairs without supervision until cleared
Do not drive until strength and coordination have recovered sufficiently and cleared by neurologist or physiatrist
Follow-up with neurology in 4-8 weeks after discharge for strength assessment and possible repeat NCS/EMG to track recovery
Adequate nutrition with high-protein diet (1.2-2.0 g/kg/day protein) supports muscle recovery
Mental health is important during recovery; report symptoms of depression, anxiety, or PTSD to healthcare provider (common after prolonged ICU stay)

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Early mobilization within 24-48 hours of ICU admission when hemodynamically stable to prevent and mitigate ICUAW
High-protein nutrition (1.2-2.0 g/kg/day) to support muscle preservation and recovery during critical illness
Smoking cessation to optimize pulmonary function and tissue oxygenation for nerve and muscle recovery
Glycemic control (target glucose 140-180 mg/dL in ICU; HbA1c <7% outpatient) to reduce ongoing neuromyopathy risk
Avoid unnecessary corticosteroids and neuromuscular blocking agents to reduce ICUAW risk in current and future ICU admissions
Graduated exercise program starting with low-intensity activities and progressing as tolerated to rebuild strength and endurance
Frequent repositioning every 2 hours during immobility to prevent pressure ulcers and contractures
Adequate sleep hygiene with consistent sleep-wake cycles to promote neurological recovery and reduce delirium
Vitamin D supplementation if deficient to support muscle function and bone health during recovery
Alcohol avoidance as alcohol worsens neuropathy and impairs muscle recovery

differential.features: Ascending paralysis, areflexia, can develop during ICU stay; antecedent infection; albuminocytologic dissociation on LP; may be monophasic; usually not associated with prolonged steroid/NMBA exposure
differential.tests: CSF analysis (elevated protein, normal WBC); NCS/EMG (demyelinating pattern in AIDP); anti-ganglioside antibodies; clinical timeline

differential.features: Fatigable weakness, ptosis, diplopia, bulbar symptoms; fluctuating course; intact reflexes (usually); responds to cholinesterase inhibitors
differential.tests: AChR and MuSK antibodies; repetitive nerve stimulation (decremental); ice pack test; edrophonium test

differential.features: History of NMBA use; resolves within hours to days of NMBA discontinuation; train-of-four monitoring shows persistent block; no sensory involvement
differential.tests: Train-of-four monitoring (incomplete recovery of twitches); clinical resolution after NMBA clearance (typically <48h); NCS/EMG normal after drug clearance

differential.features: Sensory level; upper motor neuron signs below level (hyperreflexia, Babinski); bladder dysfunction; back pain
differential.tests: MRI spine (cord compression, hemorrhage, infarction); clinical exam with sensory level

differential.features: History of rapid sodium correction; quadriparesis with pseudobulbar features; locked-in syndrome; MRI brain lesion
differential.tests: MRI brain (pontine or extrapontine demyelination on T2/FLAIR); serum sodium correction history

differential.features: Very elevated CK (typically >10,000 IU/L); dark urine; acute kidney injury; history of crush injury, statins, or seizures
differential.tests: CK markedly elevated; urine myoglobin; renal function; clinical context

differential.features: Very elevated CK; myopathic EMG; may occur with statin use in ICU; requires muscle biopsy for definitive diagnosis
differential.tests: CK markedly elevated; NCS/EMG (myopathic); muscle biopsy (necrosis without inflammation); anti-HMGCR or anti-SRP antibodies

differential.features: Proximal weakness improving with repeated effort; autonomic dysfunction; associated with small cell lung cancer; incremental response on RNS
differential.tests: Anti-VGCC antibodies; repetitive nerve stimulation (incremental at high-rate); CT chest for malignancy

differential.features: Weakness proportional to immobility duration; normal NCS/EMG; no sensory changes; normal CK
differential.tests: NCS/EMG normal; clinical context; muscle ultrasound (atrophy without echogenicity changes)

differential.features: Proximal weakness; elevated CK; delayed relaxation of reflexes; other hypothyroid features (edema, cold intolerance)
differential.tests: TSH elevated; free T4 low; CK elevated; NCS/EMG (myopathic)

differential.features: Proximal weakness; elevated CK (often >5000); skin changes in dermatomyositis; may respond to immunosuppression
differential.tests: CK markedly elevated; myositis-specific antibodies; MRI muscle (edema); muscle biopsy (inflammatory infiltrate)

differential.features: Proximal weakness; normal CK; history of chronic corticosteroid use; no sensory involvement; gradual onset
differential.tests: Normal CK; NCS/EMG (myopathic MUPs); clinical improvement with steroid taper; muscle biopsy (type 2 fiber atrophy without necrosis)

evidence.recommendation: ICUAW defined as MRC sum score <48/60 in cooperative ICU patients
Sepsis and multi-organ failure are primary risk factors for ICUAW
NCS/EMG differentiates CIM (myopathic, normal SNAPs) from CIP (axonal sensorimotor)
Direct muscle stimulation (DMS) differentiates CIM from CIP in uncooperative patients
Hyperglycemia is independent risk factor; glycemic control reduces ICUAW incidence
evidence.source: [Van den Berghe et al. NEJM 2001](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/11942631/); [Hermans et al. Lancet 2007](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18064865/)

evidence.recommendation: NICE-SUGAR target glucose 140-180 mg/dL (tight control increases mortality)
Corticosteroids combined with NMBAs greatly increase CIM risk
evidence.source: [De Jonghe et al. Crit Care Med 2009](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/20838559/); [Hermans et al. Intensive Care Med 2014](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24441670/)

evidence.recommendation: Early mobilization reduces ICUAW incidence and improves outcomes
Early mobilization is safe in mechanically ventilated patients
Minimizing sedation reduces delirium and ICUAW risk (ABCDEF bundle)
CIM has better prognosis than CIP; most CIM patients recover within 3-6 months
evidence.source: [Koch et al. Neurology 2012](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22170878/); [Guarneri et al. J Neurol Neurosurg Psychiatry 2008](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18339730/)

evidence.recommendation: Muscle ultrasound detects early muscle wasting in ICU patients
Protein intake 1.2-2.0 g/kg/day recommended for critically ill patients
No specific pharmacologic treatment proven effective for CIM or CIP
Electrical muscle stimulation may attenuate muscle wasting (emerging evidence)
ICU-acquired weakness is associated with increased mortality and prolonged mechanical ventilation
ABCDEF bundle implementation reduces ICUAW and delirium
Vitamin D deficiency is associated with ICU-acquired weakness

monitoring.item: MRC sum score (6 bilateral muscle groups: shoulder abduction, elbow flexion, wrist extension, hip flexion, knee extension, ankle dorsiflexion)
monitoring.frequency: Daily in ICU when patient cooperative; weekly on floor; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: MRC <48/60: confirm ICUAW diagnosis; intensify rehabilitation; if declining, reassess for alternative or superimposed diagnosis

monitoring.frequency: q1-2h on insulin drip; q4-6h on SC insulin; fasting + pre-meals on floor
monitoring.action: Adjust insulin regimen; avoid hypoglycemia <70 mg/dL; persistent hyperglycemia worsens ICUAW

monitoring.item: Respiratory function (FVC if cooperative; ventilator mechanics if intubated)
monitoring.frequency: q4-6h if on ventilator; daily if on floor; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: Declining FVC: assess for pneumonia, fluid overload, worsening weakness; adjust ventilator support

monitoring.frequency: q4-6h if ventilator-dependent; daily on floor
monitoring.action: NIF weaker than -20 cmH2O: not ready for extubation; continue respiratory therapy

monitoring.frequency: Weekly in ICU; monthly outpatient if diaphragm weakness present
monitoring.action: Declining values: diaphragm atrophy worsening; adjust ventilator settings to promote diaphragm activity (avoid excessive support)

monitoring.frequency: q48-72h in acute phase; weekly during recovery; PRN outpatient
monitoring.action: Persistently or newly elevated: reassess for ongoing muscle injury; rhabdomyolysis; inflammatory myopathy

monitoring.frequency: Daily in ICU; q48-72h on floor; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: Replete aggressively; hypokalemia, hypomagnesemia, hypophosphatemia all worsen weakness

monitoring.frequency: Weekly in ICU and on floor; monthly outpatient
monitoring.action: Low values: optimize nutrition; increase protein intake; nutrition consult
Over-sedation: reduce sedatives; switch from benzodiazepines to dexmedetomidine or propofol

monitoring.frequency: q8-12h in ICU; daily on floor
monitoring.action: Positive: delirium workup; reduce deliriogenic medications (benzodiazepines, anticholinergics); non-pharmacologic interventions

monitoring.frequency: Every shift in ICU; daily on floor
monitoring.action: Pressure ulcer: reposition more frequently; wound care consult; pressure-relieving mattress

monitoring.item: Functional status (Barthel Index or FIM score)
monitoring.frequency: Weekly in hospital; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: Not improving: reassess rehabilitation plan; consider transfer to higher-level rehabilitation; assess for barriers to recovery

monitoring.frequency: At 2-4 weeks after initial; repeat at 3-6 months if recovering; annually if persistent deficits
monitoring.action: No improvement at 3-6 months: consider muscle biopsy; reassess diagnosis; discuss prognosis with patient/family

monitoring.frequency: Weekly on floor; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: PHQ-9 >=10 or GAD-7 >=10: initiate treatment; psychiatry referral; assess for PTSD

disposition.criteria: MRC sum score >=48/60; ambulatory with or without assistive device; safe swallowing; adequate pain control on oral medications; stable respiratory function off supplemental O2; reliable outpatient follow-up; home exercise program established; family/caregiver support

New-onset ICUAW identified in ICU patient transitioning to floor; MRC sum score 36-48/60; hemodynamically stable; off vasopressors; not ventilator-dependent; requires ongoing PT/OT; needs continued monitoring

Ventilator-dependent with ICUAW; acute respiratory failure from neuromuscular weakness; hemodynamic instability; need for continuous monitoring; initial evaluation of weakness in critically ill patient

disposition.disposition: Transfer to higher level of care
disposition.criteria: Need for specialized electrodiagnostic testing (DMS) not available locally; complex ventilator weaning requiring neuromuscular expertise; need for muscle biopsy for atypical presentation

Significant motor deficits (MRC sum score 36-48/60); able to tolerate 3 hours/day of therapy; medically stable; off mechanical ventilation (or stable tracheostomy with portable ventilator); good prognosis for functional improvement
Ventilator-dependent >21 days; unable to tolerate intensive rehabilitation; requires ongoing skilled nursing and ventilator weaning; medically complex
Unable to tolerate 3 hours/day of therapy; requires ongoing nursing care; not ready for home but not requiring acute hospital level care
